annotations:
But what were they
 What were they
 What were they to you, to you
The narrator is concerned that the person wouldn’t have cared about the things she wanted to say. They had little regard for her

I thought of so many things
 To say to you, to you
In an unhealthy relationship, thoughts can well up inside yourself. The narrator never voiced her concerns to the ‘you,’ and is now reminiscing

search_results.title: Polyurethane
search_results.lyrics:
Polyurethane Lyrics[Verse]
I cried while polyurethane dried
Why, why do I try rememberin' this?
Like kissin' when it's all salt and stoppin' me
Walkin' right out into the oncomin'
When it ain't green I'll be
Lighter next layer in an hour
Light like kissesYou might also likeEmbed

song.embed_content: Read “Polyurethane” by Lomelda on Genius
song.title: Polyurethane

annotations:
I’ll be
 Lighter next layer in an hour
 Light like kisses

Hannah is largely an album about exploring self-identity. In “Kisses,” she states

Now I’m light, like kisses

Here, she states that she will be “lighter next layer in an hour.” She is acknowledging that the patient effort is what will bring her to the Read she is in “Kisses,” with drying polyurethane as both a process that takes time and as a process that results in a novel canvas for a new layer of herself to be painted.

Hannah begins with “Kisses,” where Read reflects on the same memory as in “Polyurethane” from a vantage that is much further, less emotional and more meditative. She is able to reflect in a way where she can engage in a different form of looking back, whereas here the memory is “green” and too fresh to properly assess.

Perhaps unintentional, the polyurethane metaphor can be extended to the chemistry of wood lacquers: generally, polyurethanes made from chemicals called “aromatic isocyanates” are preferred for their stability, but are susceptible to discoloration from light exposure over time. Polyurethane coatings are, instead, usually engineered from “aliphatic isocyanates,” which sacrifice some material properties in favor of being resistant to light discoloration over time.

In “Kisses,” Read is very concerned with the action of looking back and implies a clarity she has that she could not have when she was close to the memory. The resistance of polyurethane coatings to light discoloration emphasizes a clarity in looking back at the memory, as opposed to the events of the memory instead becoming warped and muddied with time.

Why, why do I try rememberin’ this?
 Like kissin’ when it’s all salt and stoppin’ me

In the throes of complicated emotions drawn from a painful—likely recent—memory, Read is either frustrated with her inability to help herself from recalling it when she knows it hurts her or with her insistence on trying to preserve the memory instead of let it go. Although these two frustrations intersect, the latter is metaphorically supported by the literal function of polyurethane varnish, which is as a protective coating for the preservation of wood.

The pain of memory causes tears, which the salt is in reference to. With the phrase “stoppin' me” added, it is possible that salt can have a dual meaning here as a reference to the story in the Book of Genesis where Lot’s wife turns back to see the burning city of Sodom and is turned into a pillar of salt as punishment for it. Framing the recollection of this memory as a “looking” is also done in the opener “Kisses,” where Read opens with the first line being

Lookin' at the way it went…

“Polyurethane” is directly connected to “Kisses” as it repeats the major lyrical motif of that song “light like kisses.”

Polyurethane is a type of wood varnish which typically requires multiple coats and time to dry in between.
The speaker is quite possibly using this as a metaphor for feelings of grief and loss experienced after the end of a relationship, while acknowledging that once this “drying-out” period is over, a new layer can be applied.

search_results.title: Nervous Driver
search_results.lyrics:
Nervous Driver LyricsSorry if lately I don't want to fight
I keep waiting all night to go out of my mind
If you've got a reason, I'm sure that you're right
It's not bad to be right
But if you know I am wrong
Why don't you tell me why?

Sorry if lately I give up too quick
Go flying down highways and throwing my fists
And sink in the moments and spinning for it
It's not you that I miss
But if you know I am wrong
I wish you would tell me why
Or just hold me close before you go
At least hold me close before I go
Don't know you I need a goodbye?
Cause I'm too nervous to driveYou might also likeEmbed

search_results.title: Hannah Sun
search_results.lyrics:
Hannah Sun Lyrics[Verse 1]
I sent you the sun from my hometown
And Chicago, and Atlanta
Sinking at the sight of your shadow
On the sidewalk in Spain

[Verse 2]
Or back in upstate, was it Jersey?
At the airport to Alaska
Sinking on a call from your hometown
Where they found him tearing through
[Verse 3]
Flying through the blue on your old drive
Got some old files, gotta find 'em
Gotta get 'em out, gotta get out
Gotta get good, gotta give

[Verse 4]
Sinking in again, it's forever now
Glad you held her, glad you held him
Glad you held me too, though I didn't know how to
Be closer to you

[Verse 5]
Shadowed by the blue, am I shining?
I am trying to shine
Shine

[Outro]
Hannah, do no harm
Hannah, do no harm
No harm, no harm, no harm
Hannah, do no harm, no harm
Hannah, do no harm
No harm, no harm
No harmYou might also like2Embed

description.plain:
“Hannah Sun” is the second track (and third single) from Lomelda’s 2020 album Hannah.

The song has existed since at least 2018, when singer-songwriter Hannah Read performed a solo rendition of the song, then simply titled “Hannah,” at Paste Studios in New York.

song.embed_content: Read “Hannah Sun” by Lomelda on Genius
song.title: Hannah Sun

body.plain:
“Hannah Sun” is the second track (and third single) from Lomelda’s 2020 album Hannah.

The song has existed since at least 2018, when singer-songwriter Hannah Read performed a solo rendition of the song, then simply titled “Hannah,” at Paste Studios in New York.

I was only four hours away

And saved my lifeYou might also likeEmbed

search_results.title: It’s Infinite
search_results.lyrics:
It’s Infinite LyricsLookin' left again
Like, am I forgettin'?
Probably just a dream
That I called a vision
Should I let 'em know?
After the show, I go
Chase 'em down the road
Swearing some, I shouldn't
I shouldn't
I shouldn't
Dribble down the ditch
What's that Molly's chasing?
Probably just a dream
Molly, don't be stupid
It's infinite
You'll never quit barking
Barking

Chase you down the road, swearing
I shouldn't

It's infinite
You'll never quit
Dribbling, missing
Missing

Missing
More, more, more, more, more, more missing
More missingYou might also likeEmbed

description.plain:
In a statement, Read explains, “‘It’s Infinite’ is about missin shots and missin dogs and deciding that even if I get all mad and muddy runnin after ‘em, I’m still gonna. I am still gonna sing songs and truck along towards heaven on earth til I die.”


sourced from stereogum article (https://www.stereogum.com/2093099/lomelda-its-infinite/music/)

search_results.title: Columbia River
search_results.lyrics:
Columbia River LyricsEverybody tries to make me dance but I just want to sit still
And stare right at you with my strongest gaze. It's an innocent youthful thrill
And hold your hand on my front porch swing when the summer night sends a chill
And dream of driving way up north though I know we'll never get our fill

Everybody tries to fall in love but I just keep making friends
When I sort through the stars at night I'm looking for some kind of sign of the end
If the sun won't rise when the morning comes I'll be ready 'cause I don't depend
On those things like philosophy and the sunrise, moon tides, pursuit of happiness

I find that I wish I was home
I find that I wish I was home
Singing songs that I [you] already know
Instead of always writing [singing] my own
And arranging the tones
In this city that reminds me I'm alone
I find that I wish I was yours
I find that I wish I was yours
And belonged to all the birds nesting on the porch
And all the trees along the river gorge
And every windswept metaphor --
All of yours until I am nothing moreYou might also like1Embed

song.embed_content: Read “Columbia River” by Lomelda on Genius
song.title: Columbia River
